Sustainable (open) file formats
Make sure your data remain readable 
If a file and its desired version can be located, you (or others) might still be unable to open it and read its content. 
This is more likely to happen on longer (archival) timescales, and for data sharing beyond a project team (with people lacking access to specific dedicated tools). Some decisions and actions could be postponed until later in the research process.
Proprietary vs. open formats
 
Proprietary formats often aren’t readable without the corresponding (commercial) software, and may become obsolete in the future. WordPerfect (.wpd) is just one example of a format that used to be common and popular, but is currently at most ‘exotic’. Readability of data generated by scientific instruments may depend on the underlying and not widely available software.
 
Conversion from proprietary to open formats may result in some loss of data and/or context (formatting, embedded metadata, …). In such cases, it may be advisable to save data in both proprietary and open formats – if you can no longer read the proprietary format, you then lose something but not everything … .
 
Open formats are preferred, but another reason for using (and keeping) a proprietary format could be that it is (far) more commonly used. Two aspects might require consideration when choosing file formats:
  • Is there loss of information? Uncompressed formats are preferable, but storage requirements could become prohibitive – particularly for large sets of files. Lossy compression results in permanent loss of information, effects may be limited and go unnoticed by users – a certain degree of lossy compression may be deemed acceptable. Effects can be exacerbated if a file is saved several times in a format with lossy compression (“digital generation loss”). Lossless compression is less efficient in reducing file sizes, but a file can be restored to its original state. Yet, all compressed file formats are more vulnerable to bit rot: changes in one or a few bits may cause major changes across the entire document and render it useless.
  • Is there a need to edit/manipulate saved files? For example, the .pdf format is not suitable for tabulated numerical data if access to numbers is needed for e.g. visualization, sorting, filtering, statistical analyses, …. .
File format sustainability factors
The Library of Congress defines seven “sustainability factors for digital formats” (other sources use similar criteria):
Disclosure, Adoption, Transparency, Self-documentation, (limited) external dependencies, Impact of patents, Technical protection mechanisms. Read more
 
Comprehensive coverage by Library of Congress includes discussion of various content categories (still image, sound, textual, moving image, …). The list of recommended formats is updated annually.
Recommended file formats

For some data types, there is no broad consensus on preferred formats, the following list is for indicative guidance:

 
Type of data Recommended formats Comments
Text Plain text (.txt)
Rich Text format (.rtf)
Open Document Text (.odt)
PDF (PDF/A-1)		 Encoding for all formats preferably UTF-8
Alternative: .docx (ISO standard) is acceptable but avoid proprietary formats (such as .doc)
PDF/A (pdf format for archival purposes) if layout is relevant
[see also: Notes on pdf format]

 
Tabular (minimal metadata) Comma-separated values (.csv)
Tab-delimited (.tab)		 Alternative: .xlsx (ISO standard) widely used and thus acceptable
Tabular (extensive metadata) SPSS portable format (.por)
NetCDF		 Alternative: proprietary formats of statistical packages acceptable
Images TIFF6.0 uncompressed (.tif)
JPEG2000 (.jp2)
JPEG (.jpg)
GIF (.gif)
Scalable Vector Image (.svg)		 TIFF is proprietary but widely used and well-documented
JPEG2000 provides lossless compression but isn’t widely adopted (“niche format”)
JPEG has lossy compression
.svg for vector images
Geospatial ESRI Shapefile
Geography Markup Language (.gml)
Geo-referenced TIFF		  
Video MPEG-4 (.mp4)
OGG video (.ogv, .ogg)		  
Audio Free Lossless Audio Codec (.flac)
Waveform Audio File Format (.wav)		 Alternative: MPEG-1 Audio Layer 3 (.mp3) has lossy compression, acceptable if original generated in this format
